Exaggerate: The claim exaggerates by suggesting that Chick-fil-A distributed "Back the Blue" T-shirts to employees in response to recent protests over police brutality, when in fact the shirts were made and worn to support a local high school football team.
Lack enough support: The claim lacks enough support as it only provides a photograph without any additional evidence or context.
Problematic assumption: The claim assumes that the wearing of "Back the Blue" T-shirts by Chick-fil-A employees is a direct response to protests over police brutality, without considering alternative explanations or motivations.
Exist alternative explanation: There is an alternative explanation provided by Chick-fil-A and confirmed by a representative of the company that the shirts were made in 2015 to support a local high school football team, not as a response to recent protests.
Contradict fact: The claim contradicts the fact that the photograph is several years old and was taken at one specific Chick-fil-A location in Texas, rather than being a widespread distribution of shirts by the company.
Understate: There is no evidence of understating bias in the provided claim.
